com.mesosphere.sdk.framework

Class ProcessExit

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.mesosphere.sdk.framework.ProcessExit

  • public final class ProcessExit
extends java.lang.Object
    This class handles exiting the Scheduler process, after completed teardown or after a fatal error.

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Class and Description
      static class  ProcessExit.Code
      A reason for the Scheduler process to exit.

    • Field Summary

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      static ProcessExit.Code API_SERVER_ERROR 
      static ProcessExit.Code DEADLOCK_ENCOUNTERED 
      static ProcessExit.Code DISCONNECTED 
      static ProcessExit.Code DRIVER_EXITED 
      static ProcessExit.Code ERROR 
      static ProcessExit.Code INITIALIZATION_FAILURE 
      static ProcessExit.Code LOCK_UNAVAILABLE 
      static ProcessExit.Code REGISTRATION_FAILURE 
      static ProcessExit.Code SCHEDULER_ALREADY_UNINSTALLING 
      static ProcessExit.Code SUCCESS 

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Static Methods Concrete Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      static void exit(ProcessExit.Code code)
      Immediately exits the process with the ordinal value of the provided ProcessExit.
      static void exit(ProcessExit.Code code, java.lang.Throwable e)
      Similar to #exit(ProcessExit), except also prints the stack trace of the provided exception before exiting the process.

      • Methods inherited from class java.lang.Object

        clone, equals, finalize, getClass, hashCode, notify, notifyAll, toString, wait, wait, wait

    • Method Detail

      • exit

        public static void exit(ProcessExit.Code code)
        Immediately exits the process with the ordinal value of the provided ProcessExit.

      • exit

        public static void exit(ProcessExit.Code code,
                        java.lang.Throwable e)
        Similar to #exit(ProcessExit), except also prints the stack trace of the provided exception before exiting the process. This may be used in contexts where the process is exiting in response to a thrown exception.
